abstract.name: Abstract
abstract.p: In this paper, we study the continued fraction ⁢ysr which satisfies the equation =⁢ysry+s⁢2rr⁢+s1-+s⁢2r1 for >r12. This continued fraction is a generalization of the Brouncker’s continued fraction ⁢bs. We extend the formulas for the first and the second logarithmic derivatives of ⁢bs to the case of ⁢ysr. The asymptotic series for ⁢ysr at ∞ are also studied. The generalizations of some Ramanujan’s formulas are presented.
Keywords: Brouncker’s continued fraction, Ramanujan’s formula, Asymptotic series, Functional equations. Primary 11A55 Secondary 11J70, 30B70.

p.text: Generalized Brouncker’s continued fractions and their logarithmic derivatives

para.p: Institut für Mathematik, MA 4-5, Technische Universität Berlin,
D-10623 Berlin, Germany

The Brouncker’s continued fraction =⁢bs+sK=n1∞-⁢2n12⁢2s still attracts the attention of researchers due to its role in the theory of orthogonal polynomials and its relations to the Gamma and Beta functions (see [], []–[]). Recall the following theorem of Brouncker describing the properties of ⁢bs (see [], p. 145, Theorem 3.16).

p.text: Let ⁢bs be a function on 0+∞ satisfying the functional equation =⁢bsb+s2+s12 and the inequality <s⁢bs for >sC, where C is some constant. Then

para.p: Ramanujan discovered the formula, expressing the Brouncker’s continued fraction in terms of the Gamma function (see [], p. 153, Theorem 3.25).
The following extension of Brouncker’s theorem (Theorem 1) was obtained by Euler (see [], p. 180, Theorem 4.17).

p.text: Let ⁢ysr be a positive continuous function satisfying the inequality <s⁢ysr and the equation

Math.text: y * open-interval@(s, r) * y * open-interval@(s + 2 * r, r) = (s + 1) * ((s + 2 * r) - 1)

para.p: In [] Ramanujan’s theorem (Theorem 2) was extended to the case of the continued fraction ⁢ysr (see [], p. 220, ex. 4.22).
The following exact continued fraction representation for the first logarithmic derivative of ⁢bs

Math.text: (b ^ prime / b) * s = 1 / (s + ((K _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@(n ^ 2 / s))

para.p: allows one to obtain the exponential representation for ⁢bs (see [], p. 192, Theorem 4.25).
In this paper, we represent the first logarithmic derivative of ⁢ysr in the form of the sum of two continued fractions (see Section 4, Corollary 3). For >s-r1, >r12

Math.text: (partial-differential / partial-differential@(s)) * natural-logarithm@(y) * open-interval@(s, r) = f _ 1 * open-interval@(s, r) + f _ 2 * open-interval@(s, r)

para.p: where
and
Then we extend Theorem 5 to the case of ⁢ysr (see Section 5, Theorem 9).

Math.text: y * open-interval@(s, r) = s + ((K _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@(((2 * n - 1) ^ 2 * r ^ 2 - (r - 1) ^ 2) / (2 * s)) = absent

absent = 8 * pi * r * 2 ^ (1 - 1 / r) * ((Gamma ^ 2 * (1 / (2 * r))) / (Gamma ^ 4 * (1 / (4 * r)))) * cotangent@(pi / (4 * r)) * exponential@(((integral _ 0) ^ s)@((f _ 1 * open-interval@(t, r) + f _ 2 * open-interval@(t, r)) * d * t))

p.text: where ⁢f1tr and ⁢f2tr are given by formulas (1) and (2), respectively.

para.p: There is also an exact integral representation of ⁢b′bs (see [], p. 191, Formula 4.71). For >s0

Math.text: (b ^ prime / b) * s = 1 / (s + ((K _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@(n ^ 2 / s)) = 2 * ((integral _ 0) ^ (+ infinity))@((e ^ (- s * x) * d * x) / hyperbolic-cosine@(x))

para.p: Theorem 5 together with (3) imply the following asymptotic relation, which holds for ⁢bs as →s+∞ (see [], p. 192, Corollary 4.26).

Math.text: b * s = s + ((K _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@((2 * n - 1) ^ 2 / (2 * s)) similar-to s * exponential@(- ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ infinity)@(E _ (2 * k) / (2 * k * s ^ (2 * k))))

para.p: where E⁢2k are the Euler’s numbers. Here the asymptotic power series exp-∑=k1∞E⁢2k⁢2ks⁢2k arises from replacing x in the formal power series =expx∑=n0∞xn!n by -∑=k1∞E⁢2k⁢2ks⁢2k and combining coefficients afterwards (on the possibility of such a substitution see [], p. 15, Theorem 124, see also [], p. 15).
We obtain exact integral representations for both the continued fractions (1) and (2) (see Section 3, Lemma 4). For >s-r1, >r12
These two formulas together with Theorem 9 allows us to obtain the asymptotic expansion for ⁢ysr at infinity (see Section 6, Theorem 10), using Euler’s methods.

Math.text: y * open-interval@(s, r) = s + ((K _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@(((2 * n - 1) ^ 2 * r ^ 2 - (r - 1) ^ 2) / (2 * s)) similar-to absent

absent similar-to s * exponential@(- ((sum _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@(((sum _ (k = 0)) ^ n)@(binomial@(2 * n, 2 * k) * (r - 1) ^ (2 * k) * r ^ (2 * (n - k)) * E _ (2 * (n - k))) / (2 * n * s ^ (2 * n))))

para.p: Let us introduce the notation:

Math.text: (s ^ 2 - 1) + ((4 * 1 ^ 2) / 1) * STACKED@(absent, +) * ((4 * 1 ^ 2) / (s ^ 2 - 1)) * STACKED@(absent, +) * ((4 * 2 ^ 2) / 1) * STACKED@(absent, +) * ((4 * 2 ^ 2) / (s ^ 2 - 1)) * STACKED@(absent, +) * STACKED@(absent, cdots) = (s ^ 2 - 1) + (((K ^ prime) _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@(((4 * n ^ 2) / 1) * STACKED@(absent, +) * ((4 * n ^ 2) / (s ^ 2 - 1)))

para.p: Ramanujan stated the following formula for the second logarithmic derivative of ⁢bs, which was proved later by Perron (see [], p. 231, Formula (5.6), see also []).

Math.text: (natural-logarithm@(b)) ^ prime2 * s = - ((integral _ 0) ^ infinity)@(((x * e ^ (- s * x)) / hyperbolic-cosine@(x)) * d * x) = - 1 / ((s ^ 2 - 1) + (((K ^ prime) _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@(((4 * n ^ 2) / 1) * STACKED@(absent, +) * ((4 * n ^ 2) / (s ^ 2 - 1))))

para.p: We obtain the corresponding formula for the second logarithmic derivative of ⁢ysr.

Math.text: (partial-differential ^ 2 / partial-differential@(s ^ 2)) * natural-logarithm@(y) * open-interval@(s, r) = - (1 / (2 * r ^ 2)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ infinity)@(((x * (e ^ (- (((1 - r) + s) / r) * x) + e ^ (- (((r - 1) + s) / r) * x))) / hyperbolic-cosine@(x)) * d * x) = - h _ 1 * open-interval@(s, r) - h _ 2 * open-interval@(s, r)

para.p: Let us recall the following statement, which will be used later (see [], p. 152, Lemma 3.23).

p.text: Let ⁢gs be a monotonic function on 0∞, vanishing at infinity, and >a0 be a positive number. Then the functional equation =+⁢fs⁢f+sa⁢gs has a unique solution, vanishing at infinity, given by the formula

Math.text: f * s = ((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ infinity)@((- 1) ^ n * g * (s + n * a))

para.p: Let us prove two following statements for the first and the second logarithmic derivatives of ⁢ysr.

p.text: has a unique solution, satisfying =lim→s∞⁢fsr0, which is

Math.text: f * open-interval@(s, r) = (partial-differential / partial-differential@(s)) * natural-logarithm@(y) * open-interval@(s, r)

para.p: Proof. The equality =⁢ysry+s⁢2rr⁢+s1-+s⁢2r1 implies

Math.text: natural-logarithm@(y * open-interval@(s, r) * y * open-interval@(s + 2 * r, r)) = natural-logarithm@((s + 1) * ((s + 2 * r) - 1))

para.p: Differentiating by s, we obtain

Math.text: ((partial-differential / partial-differential@(s)) * y * open-interval@(s, r)) / (y * open-interval@(s, r)) + ((partial-differential / partial-differential@(s)) * y * open-interval@(s + 2 * r, r)) / (y * open-interval@(s + 2 * r, r)) = 1 / (s + 1) + 1 / ((s + 2 * r) - 1)

para.p: The function =⁢fs⁢⁢∂∂syysr satisfy the conditions of Lemma 1 with =a⁢2r and =⁢gs⁢2+sr⁢+s1-+s⁢2r1. Applying Lemma 1, we complete the proof. □
Let us examine two equations:

Math.text: f _ 1 * open-interval@(s, r) + f _ 1 * open-interval@(s + 2 * r, r) = 1 / (s + 1)

para.p: and

Math.text: f _ 2 * open-interval@(s, r) + f _ 2 * open-interval@(s + 2 * r, r) = 1 / ((s + 2 * r) - 1)

para.p: Both of them satisfy the conditions of Lemma 1 with =a⁢2r, =⁢gs1+s1 and =⁢gs1-+s⁢2r1, respectively. So, applying Lemma 1, we obtain, that the solution ⁢f1sr of equation (7) which satisfies =lim→s∞⁢f1sr0 is unique. The solution ⁢f2sr of equation (8) which satisfies =lim→s∞⁢f2sr0 is also unique. Since their sum +⁢f1sr⁢f2sr satisfies equation (5), we have from Lemma 2, that

Math.text: (partial-differential / partial-differential@(s)) * natural-logarithm@(y) * open-interval@(s, r) = f _ 1 * open-interval@(s, r) + f _ 2 * open-interval@(s, r)

para.p: where ⁢f1sr and ⁢f2sr are the solutions of (7) and (8), respectively, vanishing as →s+∞.

Math.text: f * open-interval@(s, r) + f * open-interval@(s + 2 * r, r) = - 1 / (s + 1) ^ 2 - 1 / ((s + 2 * r) - 1) ^ 2

p.text: has a unique solution, satisfying =lim→s∞⁢fsr0, which is

Math.text: f * open-interval@(s, r) = (partial-differential ^ 2 / (partial-differential ^ 2)@(s)) * natural-logarithm@(y) * open-interval@(s, r)

para.p: Proof. Differentiate equation (6) once again by s:

Math.text: (partial-differential / partial-differential@(s)) * (((partial-differential / partial-differential@(s)) * y * open-interval@(s, r)) / (y * open-interval@(s, r))) + (partial-differential / partial-differential@(s)) * (((partial-differential / partial-differential@(s)) * y * open-interval@(s + 2 * r, r)) / (y * open-interval@(s + 2 * r, r))) = - 1 / (s + 1) ^ 2 - 1 / ((s + 2 * r) - 1) ^ 2

para.p: Applying Lemma 1 with =a⁢2r and =⁢gs--1+s121-+s⁢2r12, we complete the proof. □
Repeating the above reasoning, we obtain that

Math.text: - (partial-differential ^ 2 / (partial-differential ^ 2)@(s)) * natural-logarithm@(y) * open-interval@(s, r) = h _ 1 * open-interval@(s, r) + h _ 2 * open-interval@(s, r)

para.p: where ⁢h1s is the unique solution of the equation

Math.text: h _ 1 * open-interval@(s, r) + h _ 1 * open-interval@(s + 2 * r, r) = 1 / (s + 1) ^ 2

para.p: satisfying =lim→s∞⁢h1sr0 and ⁢h2s is the unique solution of the equation

section.title: 3Exact integral representation for certain type continued fractions

para.p: To begin, we formulate the following result by Euler (see [] and [], p. 191, Theorem 4.24).

Math.text: 1 / (s + ((K _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@(n ^ 2 / s)) = ((integral _ 0) ^ (+ infinity))@((e ^ (- s * x) * d * x) / hyperbolic-cosine@(x))

para.p: Let us formulate and prove the following lemma.

p.text: Let ⁢φsr be an arbitrary real-valued function of s and r. Then for >r0, >⁢φsr0Actually we have the condition >⁢φsrr0 but since in the conditions of Theorem 3 >r12 we restrict ourselves to the case >r0.

Math.text: 1 / (2 * varphi * open-interval@(s, r) + 2 * ((K _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@((n ^ 2 * r ^ 2) / (varphi * open-interval@(s, r)))) = (1 / r) * ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@((x ^ ((varphi * open-interval@(r, s)) / r) * d * x) / (1 + x ^ 2))

para.p: Proof. Examine equality (13). Using the substitution :=s⁢φsrr, where ⁢φsr is an arbitrary real-valued function of s and r, we obtain the equality, which is correct for all sr satisfying >⁢φsr0, >r0.

Math.text: 1 / ((varphi * open-interval@(s, r)) / r + ((K _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@(n ^ 2 / (varphi * open-interval@(s, r)) / r)) = 2 * ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@((x ^ ((varphi * open-interval@(s, r)) / r) * d * x) / (1 + x ^ 2))

1 / (2 * varphi * open-interval@(s, r) + 2 * r * ((K _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@(n ^ 2 / (varphi * open-interval@(s, r)) / r)) = (1 / r) * ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@((x ^ ((varphi * open-interval@(s, r)) / r) * d * x) / (1 + x ^ 2))

para.p: Let us apply the equivalence transform with the parameters =r01, =rnr, =n12… to the continued fraction on the left-hand side. This results the formula:

Math.text: 1 / (2 * varphi * open-interval@(s, r) + 2 * ((K _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@((n ^ 2 * r ^ 2) / (varphi * open-interval@(s, r)))) = (1 / r) * ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@((x ^ ((varphi * open-interval@(s, r)) / r) * d * x) / (1 + x ^ 2))

1 / (varphi * open-interval@(s, r) + ((K _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@((n ^ 2 * r ^ 2) / (varphi * open-interval@(s, r)))) = (1 / r) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (+ infinity))@((e ^ (- ((varphi * open-interval@(r, s)) / r) * x) * d * x) / hyperbolic-cosine@(x))

para.p: Proof. It is enough for the proof to use the substitution :=xe-x. □
Example. Let =⁢φsr+ssinr, =s1, =rπ2. Then

Math.text: 1 / (2 + ((K _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@((n ^ 2 * (pi ^ 2 / 4)) / 2)) = (2 / pi) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (+ infinity))@((e ^ (- (4 / pi) * x) * d * x) / hyperbolic-cosine@(x))

para.p: Using the equivalence transformation with the parameters =r01, =rn2, =n1 2…, we get

Math.text: 1 / (4 + ((K _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@((n ^ 2 * pi ^ 2) / 4)) = (1 / pi) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (+ infinity))@((e ^ (- (4 / pi) * x) * d * x) / hyperbolic-cosine@(x))

section.title: 4Functional equations for certain type continued fractions

para.p: Now let us formulate and prove the following theorem.

p.text: Let =⁢φsr+s⁢ψr, where ⁢ψr is an arbitrary real-valued function of r. Then for >r0, >s-⁢ψr the continued fraction of the form

Math.text: f * open-interval@(s, r) = 1 / (2 * varphi * open-interval@(s, r) + 2 * ((K _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@((n ^ 2 * r ^ 2) / (varphi * open-interval@(s, r))))

p.text: is the unique solution of the functional equation

Math.text: f * open-interval@(s, r) + f * open-interval@(s + 2 * r, r) = 1 / (varphi * open-interval@(s, r) + r)

para.p: Proof. Examine the series expansion for the right-hand side of equation (15):

Math.text: (1 / r) * ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@((x ^ ((varphi * open-interval@(s, r)) / r) * d * x) / (1 + x ^ 2)) = (1 / r) * ((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ infinity)@((- 1) ^ n * ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(x ^ (2 * n + (varphi * open-interval@(s, r)) / r) * d * x)) = (1 / r) * ((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ infinity)@((- 1) ^ n / ((varphi * open-interval@(s, r)) / r + 2 * n + 1)) = absent
absent = ((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ infinity)@((- 1) ^ n / (varphi * open-interval@(s, r) + 2 * r * n + r))

para.p: It follows from Lemma 1, that the unique solution of equation (16) satisfying =lim→s∞⁢fsr0 is given by the formula:

Math.text: f * open-interval@(s, r) = ((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ infinity)@((- 1) ^ n / (varphi * open-interval@(s + 2 * r * n, r) + r))

para.p: Since =⁢φsr+s⁢ψr, we have

Math.text: f * open-interval@(s, r) = ((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ infinity)@((- 1) ^ n / (varphi * open-interval@(s + 2 * r * n, r) + r)) = ((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ infinity)@((- 1) ^ n / (varphi * open-interval@(s, r) + 2 * r * n + r)) = absent

para.p: by Lemma 4. □

p.text: For >s-r1, >r0 functional equation (7) has a unique solution satisfying =lim→s0⁢f1sr0 which is
Functional equation (8) also has a unique solution satisfying =lim→s0⁢f2sr0 which is

para.p: Proof. From the equality =1+s11+⁢φ1srr we obtain =⁢φ1sr-+s1r. Since ⁢φ1sr satisfies the conditions of Theorem 8, we obtain, that the continued fraction ⁢f1sr is the solution of (7). By analogy, from the equality =1-+s⁢2r11+⁢φ2srr we obtain =⁢φ2sr-+sr1, which also satisfies the conditions of Theorem 8. Applying Theorem 8 again, we obtain that the continued fraction ⁢f2sr is the solution of (8). □

absent = 8 * pi * r * 2 ^ (1 - 1 / r) * ((Gamma ^ 2 * (1 / (2 * r))) / (Gamma ^ 4 * (1 / (4 * r)))) * cotangent@(pi / (4 * r)) * exponential@(((integral _ 0) ^ s)@(f _ 1 * open-interval@(t, r) * d * t)) * exponential@(((integral _ 0) ^ s)@(f _ 2 * open-interval@(t, r) * d * t))

para.p: Proof. According to Corollary 3, the continued fractions ⁢f1sr and ⁢f2sr satisfy equations (7) and (8), respectively. Hence applying Lemma 2 we obtain, that

Math.text: (partial-differential / partial-differential@(s)) * natural-logarithm@(y) * open-interval@(s, r) = 1 / ((2 - 2 * r) + 2 * s + 2 * ((K _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@((n ^ 2 * r ^ 2) / ((1 - r) + s))) + 1 / ((2 * r - 2) + 2 * s + 2 * ((K _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@((n ^ 2 * r ^ 2) / ((r - 1) + s)))

para.p: Integrating the obtained differential equation, we get

Math.text: natural-logarithm@(y) * open-interval@(s, r) = ((integral _ 0) ^ s)@((f _ 1 * open-interval@(t, r) + f _ 2 * open-interval@(t, r)) * d * t) + C * r
y * open-interval@(s, r) = C * r * exponential@(((integral _ 0) ^ s)@((f _ 1 * open-interval@(t, r) + f _ 2 * open-interval@(t, r)) * d * t))

para.p: where ⁢Cr is a function of r.
It is easy to see, that =⁢Cr⁢y0r. Let us calculate ⁢y0r, using Theorem 4. At first let us recall some well-known formulas for the Gamma function. These are the diplication formula

Math.text: Gamma * z * Gamma * (z + 1 / 2) = 2 ^ (1 - 2 * z) * square-root@(pi) * Gamma * 2 * z

para.p: and the Euler’s reflection formula

Math.text: Gamma * (1 - z) * Gamma * z = pi / sine@(pi * z)

para.p: Since by definition =⁢Γ+z1⁢zΓz, we have =⁢Γ-1z-⁢zΓ-z and rewrite the Euler’s reflection formula in the following form

Math.text: Gamma * z * Gamma * (- z) = - pi / (z * sine@(pi * z))

section.title: 6Generalized Brouncker’s continued fraction and its asymptotic series

para.p: Let us recall the following lemma (see [], p. 614, also [], p. 150, Lemma 3.21).

p.text: Let f be a function on 0+∞, such that <⁢ftM for >tϵ and =⁢ft∑=k0∞⁢cktk, 0<t<⁢2ϵ. Then

Math.text: formulae@(((integral _ 0) ^ (+ infinity))@(f * t * e ^ (- s * t) * d * t) similar-to ((sum _ (k = 0)) ^ infinity)@((kfactorial * c _ k) / s ^ (k + 1)), s rightarrow + infinity)

p.text: is the asymptotic expansion for the Laplace transform of f.

para.p: Let us write the asymptotic expansions for both continued fractions (17) and (18). Applying Corollary 2, we get the following formulas for >s-r1, >r0:
Examine equation (20). Write the right-hand side of equation (20) in the following form:

Math.text: (1 / (2 * r)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (+ infinity))@((e ^ (- x * (((1 - r) + s) / r)) * d * x) / hyperbolic-cosine@(x)) = (1 / (2 * r)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (+ infinity))@(e ^ (((r - 1) / r) * x) * (1 / hyperbolic-cosine@(x)) * e ^ (- (s / r) * x) * d * x)

Math.text: 1 / hyperbolic-cosine@(x) = ((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ infinity)@((E _ n / nfactorial) * x ^ n)

Math.text: (1 / (2 * r)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (+ infinity))@((e ^ (- x * (((1 - r) + s) / r)) * d * x) / hyperbolic-cosine@(x)) similar-to (1 / (2 * r)) * ((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ infinity)@(nfactorial * ((sum _ (k = 0)) ^ n)@(((r - 1) ^ k / (r ^ k * kfactorial)) * (E _ (n - k) / (n - k)factorial)) * (r ^ (n + 1) / s ^ (n + 1)))

Math.text: y * open-interval@(0, r) * exponential@(((integral _ 0) ^ (+ infinity))@(gamma _ 1 * open-interval@(t, r) * d * t)) * exponential@(((integral _ 0) ^ (+ infinity))@(gamma _ 2 * open-interval@(t, r) * d * t)) = 1

para.p: and

Math.text: absent * exponential@(- (1 / 2) * ((sum _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@((((sum _ (k = 0)) ^ n)@(binomial@(n, k) * (1 - r) ^ k * r ^ (n - k) * E _ (n - k)) - (- 1) ^ n) / (n * s ^ n)))

para.p: Using the equality =∑=n1∞-1n⁢nsn-ln+s1s as >s1, we obtain that

Math.text: y * open-interval@(s, r) similar-to s * exponential@(- (1 / 2) * ((sum _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@(((sum _ (k = 0)) ^ n)@(binomial@(n, k) * ((r - 1) ^ k + (1 - r) ^ k) * r ^ (n - k) * E _ (n - k)) / (n * s ^ n))) = absent
absent = s * exponential@(- ((sum _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@(((sum _ (k = 0)) ^ (n / 2))@(binomial@(n, 2 * k) * (r - 1) ^ (2 * k) * r ^ (n - 2 * k) * E _ (n - 2 * k)) / (n * s ^ n)))

para.p: The proof is completed by observing that all the Euler’s numbers with odd parameters E1, E3, E5, … are equal to zero. □
Example. Putting =r2 we obtain

Math.text: s + ((K _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@((4 * (2 * n - 1) ^ 2 - 1) / (2 * s)) similar-to s * exponential@(- ((sum _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@(((sum _ (k = 0)) ^ n)@(binomial@(2 * n, 2 * k) * 2 ^ (2 * (n - k)) * E _ (2 * (n - k))) / (2 * n * s ^ (2 * n))))

para.p: as →s+∞. Computations with the first few Euler’s numbers =E01, =E10, =E2-1, =E30, =E45, =E50, =E6-61 shows that =∑=k01⁢2⁢2k2⁢2-1kE⁢2-1k-3 for =n1, =∑=k02⁢4⁢2k2⁢2-2kE⁢2-2k57 for =n2 and =∑=k03⁢6⁢2k2⁢2-3kE⁢2-3k-2763 for =n3.
So we have
Writing the first terms of the expansion of ex

Math.text: e ^ x similar-to 1 + x + x ^ 2 / 2 + x ^ 3 / 6 + O * x ^ 4

para.p: and substituting =x+-3⁢2s257⁢4s42763⁢6s6⁢O1s8 we obtain the first terms of the expansion:
Our generalization of Ramanujan’s formula (4) requires some preliminary results. The first of them is the following theorem.

p.text: Let ⁢φsr be an arbitrary real-valued function of s and r. Then for >r0, >⁢φsrr

Math.text: 1 / ((varphi * open-interval@(s, r) - r ^ 2) + (((K ^ prime) _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@(((4 * n ^ 2) / 1) * STACKED@(absent, +) * ((4 * n ^ 2) / (varphi * open-interval@(s, r) - r ^ 2)))) = (1 / r ^ 2) * ((integral _ 0) ^ infinity)@(((x * e ^ (- x * ((varphi * open-interval@(s, r)) / r))) / hyperbolic-cosine@(x)) * d * x)

para.p: Proof. Examine equality (4) with the substitution :=s⁢φsrr, where ⁢φsr is an arbitrary real-valued function of s and r. Then we obtain the following formula for >⁢φsrr, >r0:

Math.text: 1 / (((varphi ^ 2 * open-interval@(s, r)) / r ^ 2 - 1) + (((K ^ prime) _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@(((4 * n ^ 2) / 1) * STACKED@(absent, +) * ((4 * n ^ 2) / ((varphi ^ 2 * open-interval@(s, r)) / r ^ 2 - 1)))) = ((integral _ 0) ^ infinity)@(((x * e ^ (- x * ((varphi * open-interval@(s, r)) / r))) / hyperbolic-cosine@(x)) * d * x)

1 / ((varphi ^ 2 * open-interval@(s, r) - r ^ 2) + r ^ 2 * (((K ^ prime) _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@(((4 * n ^ 2) / 1) * STACKED@(absent, +) * ((4 * n ^ 2) / ((varphi ^ 2 * open-interval@(s, r)) / r ^ 2 - 1)))) = (1 / r ^ 2) * ((integral _ 0) ^ infinity)@(((x * e ^ (- x * ((varphi * open-interval@(s, r)) / r))) / hyperbolic-cosine@(x)) * d * x)

para.p: Apply the equivalence transform with the parameters =r01, =rnr2, =n1 2… to the continued fraction on the left-hand side. This results the formula:

Math.text: 1 / ((varphi ^ 2 * open-interval@(s, r) - r ^ 2) + (((K ^ prime) _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@(((4 * n ^ 2 * r ^ 4) / r ^ 2) * STACKED@(absent, +) * ((4 * n ^ 2 * r ^ 4) / (varphi ^ 2 * open-interval@(s, r) - r ^ 2)))) = (1 / r ^ 2) * ((integral _ 0) ^ infinity)@(((x * e ^ (- x * ((varphi * open-interval@(s, r)) / r))) / hyperbolic-cosine@(x)) * d * x)

para.p: Using simple calculations:

Math.text: 1 / ((varphi ^ 2 * open-interval@(s, r) - r ^ 2) + (((K ^ prime) _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@(((4 * n ^ 2 * r ^ 2) / 1) * STACKED@(absent, +) * ((4 * n ^ 2 * r ^ 2) / (varphi ^ 2 * open-interval@(s, r) - r ^ 2)))) = (1 / r ^ 2) * ((integral _ 0) ^ infinity)@(((x * e ^ (- x * ((varphi * open-interval@(s, r)) / r))) / hyperbolic-cosine@(x)) * d * x)

para.p: Let us prove the following lemma, which describes the derivative of the continued fraction

Math.text: f * open-interval@(s, r) = 1 / (varphi * open-interval@(s, r) + ((K _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@((n ^ 2 * r ^ 2) / (varphi * open-interval@(s, r))))

p.text: Let =⁢φsr+s⁢ψr, where ⁢ψr is an arbitrary real-valued function of r. Then for >r0, >s-r⁢ψr

Math.text: (partial-differential / partial-differential@(s)) * f * open-interval@(s, r) = - 1 / ((varphi ^ 2 * open-interval@(s, r) - r ^ 2) + (((K ^ prime) _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@(((4 * n ^ 2 * r ^ 2) / 1) * STACKED@(absent, +) * ((4 * n ^ 2 * r ^ 2) / (varphi ^ 2 * open-interval@(s, r) - r ^ 2))))
f * open-interval@(s, r) = 1 / (varphi * open-interval@(s, r) + ((K _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@((n ^ 2 * r ^ 2) / (varphi * open-interval@(s, r))))

para.p: Proof. Using Corollary 2, we obtain the equality

Math.text: f * open-interval@(s, r) = 1 / (varphi * open-interval@(s, r) + ((K _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@((n ^ 2 * r ^ 2) / (varphi * open-interval@(s, r)))) = (1 / r) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (+ infinity))@((e ^ (- x * ((varphi * open-interval@(r, s)) / r)) * d * x) / hyperbolic-cosine@(x))

para.p: Differentiating this equality by s and changing the sign, we obtain:

Math.text: - (partial-differential / partial-differential@(s)) * f * open-interval@(s, r) = (1 / r ^ 2) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (+ infinity))@((x * e ^ (- ((varphi * open-interval@(r, s)) / r) * x) * d * x) / hyperbolic-cosine@(x))

para.p: which exactly coincide with the right-hand side of (26). □

Math.text: (partial-differential / partial-differential@(s)) * f _ 1 * open-interval@(s, r) = - 1 / (2 * ((1 - 2 * r) + s) * (1 + s) + 2 * (((K ^ prime) _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@(((4 * n ^ 2 * r ^ 2) / 1) * STACKED@(absent, +) * ((4 * n ^ 2 * r ^ 2) / (((1 - 2 * r) + s) * (1 + s)))))

(partial-differential / partial-differential@(s)) * f _ 2 * open-interval@(s, r) = - 1 / (2 * ((2 * r - 1) + s) * (s - 1) + 2 * (((K ^ prime) _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@(((4 * n ^ 2 * r ^ 2) / 1) * STACKED@(absent, +) * ((4 * n ^ 2 * r ^ 2) / (((2 * r - 1) + s) * (s - 1)))))

para.p: Example. Put =⁢φsr+ssinr, =rπ2. Then for >s-π21 we have
where

Math.text: (partial-differential ^ 2 / partial-differential@(s ^ 2)) * natural-logarithm@(y) * open-interval@(s, r) = - (1 / (2 * r ^ 2)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ infinity)@(((x * (e ^ (- (((1 - r) + s) / r) * x) + e ^ (- (((r - 1) + s) / r) * x))) / hyperbolic-cosine@(x)) * d * x) = - h _ 1 * open-interval@(s, r) - h _ 2 * open-interval@(s, r)

para.p: Proof. The proof comes out from Equality 10 and Corollary 5. □
